text.sentence: Financial Services | U.S. Brokers, Asset Managers and Exchanges three February two thousand sixteen Stock Rating
five: On the operating side, better expense cuts than forecast and roughly in line revenue helped drive a dollar sixteenmn operating beat vs. our model.
Overall, the quarter was fairly solid when excluding the AUM metrics.

Based on the stock price performance today, we believe that investors liked the capital returns and expense reductions, but we remain cautious given the bigger issue of challenging flows/returns weighing on forward EPS estimates.
Elevated capital return and progress on expense cuts encourages the bulls: Despite the uninspiring flow environment, capital return and expenses beat our forecasts heading into today.
The firm repurchased dollar four hundred fourmn in shares in FoneQ and shows no sign of slowing down the buyback.

Management spoke to an attractive M and A environment given depreciation in AM valuations and currencies; while hopeful, we remain unsure that BEN will put its foreign cash to work in the near term given its conservative history.
Lastly on the capital side, BEN upped the quarterly dividend twenty percent to dollar .eighteen from dollar .fifteen .
On the expense side, management reiterated its expectations for a three four percent decline, but believes it is probable they will realize the higher end of that range.

Flow picture still very uncertain: BEN's outflows were more significant than expected at dollar twenty onebn vs. our dollar eighteenbn estimate, driven by continuing retail outflows in a number of the firm's flagship funds.
While we like the momentum on the institutional side, particularly out of Asia, those flows are not nearly enough to offset the retail outflows.
In addition, the mix shift to institutional / HNWI is unfavorable given that retail outflows are occurring in higher fee products.
We remain cautious on flows given the market environment QTD and still challenged relative performance metrics.
Estimates coming down: Our Ftwo thousand sixteenE EPS moves to dollar two.sixty seven as we push through the market performance QTD and a reduced flow outlook given the environment.
Our price target moves to dollar thirty two from dollar thirty five, applying the same twelvex P/E to our new Ftwo thousand sixteenE EPS.

Price USD thirty two.seventy six Price Target USD thirty two.
BEN has great global capabilities with a solid suite of products in equity, fixed income, alternatives, and hybrid.
However, we expect growth below peers due to challenged relative performance trends, and a high fee, active only product set.

If we were to see significant market appreciation and better than expected performance in key asset classes such as global fixed income and equity, we could argue for multiple expansion to seventeen.fivex.
If performance were to decline and markets became unfavorable, we would expect multiple contraction to ninex.

shares at a solid clip in the quarter, with dollar four hundred fourmn of repurchases after last quarter's dollar five hundredmn.

Based on management's comments on the call, we expect the firm to return capital at an elevated rate for the remainder of Ftwo thousand sixteen given the low share price and the firm's commitment to enhance EPS through a challenging macro environment.
In addition, management pointed to solid cash flow generation, with cash remaining steady over the last year despite the elevated repurchases we have seen the last few quarters.
Outside of buybacks, BEN mentioned its continued interest in M and A, particularly outside of the US given more attractive valuations and the strengthening of the dollar vs. global currencies.
reported net outflows for the quarter of dollar twenty onebn vs. our dollar eighteenbn estimate.
Outflows were driven by dollar twenty threebn of retail outflows, while institutional posted inflows of dollar threebn, driven by a dollar five.fivebn funding from an Asian client in global macro.
Like last quarter, retail outflows were driven by the flagship funds, in particular Franklin Income, Templeton Global Bond, and Global Total Return.
Looking forward, we remain bearish on the retail outlook, and expect that the very challenging market environment QTD will likely negatively impact flows in FtwoQ.
We like the institutional flow momentum, but would also point out that the mix shift to institutional and HNWI vs. retail will remain a headwind for blended fee rates.
We are currently expecting dollar fourteenbn of outflows in FtwoQ and dollar forty ninebn of outflows for the full fiscal year.

During the quarter management highlighted a few specific trends: o US retail outflows were driven by outflows in flagship funds as well as redemptions from BEN's sub advised variable annuity business .
International retail outflows slowed due to a decrease in redemptions from the three largest cross border funds: Templeton Global Bond, Global Total Return, and Asian Growth.
Institutional flows were impacted by an Asian client adding dollar five.fivebn to a global macro mandate in the quarter.
The firm continues to see strength out of Asia, and expects the momentum to continue as it builds relationships in the region.
November, the firm filed registration statements for an initial suite of strategic beta ETFs .
The firm believes the demand is enough to make it a worthwhile endeavour into the crowded smart beta ETF space, though we believe uptake will take some time.
percent to AUM in the quarter, including a negative dollar one.sixbn
While relative performance did tick up for the one year period, performance softened sequentially over a threey, fivey, and teny time horizon.
Currently, twenty eight percent of equity and hybrid AUM and thirty eight percent of fixed income AUM is above peers on a one year basis.
We believe challenged relative performance metrics now impacting the longer term time periods will make it difficult to generate flows until well after performance initially improves.
On the call the company provided the following disclosures on forward guidance:
distribution expense, but believes the firm will likely realize the upper end of that range and is looking for ways to go beyond four percent.
Total revenues came in dollar threemn above our modeled expectations, while total expenses came in dollar fourteenmn lower .
The lower expenses and better revenue drove a dollar sixteenmn operating beat vs. our forecast.
percent, above our estimate for thirty six.three percent, but below last quarter's thirty eight.three
Below the line items offset some of the operating upside, but EPS remained above our expectations .
Revenues of dollar one thousand seven hundred fifty eightmn came in above our dollar one thousand seven hundred fifty fivemn forecast .

The beat was primarily a product of other revenue coming in dollar sevenmn higher than our model and management fees dollar onemn better, with sales and distribution and shareholder servicing removing dollar sixmn of the upside, netting to a dollar threemn
Overall, most expense line items finished under our expectations as BEN implemented cost saves at a faster rate than we were forecasting.
The biggest positive deltas were in sales, distribution, and marketing, and comp, with information, systems, and technology as well as occupancy each coming in dollar twomn better.
Non operating income came in dollar twenty onemn above our forecast .
Investment income of dollar thirty.fivemn was well above our dollar tenmn estimate.
This was driven by equity method investments, which drove a dollar twenty fivemn gain.
Flows came in worse than expected at dollar twenty onebn vs. our dollar eighteenbn estimate.
Outflows were broad based but concentrated in hybrid, global/international fixed income, and global/international equity.
Outflows were driven by retail, with institutional benefitting from a dollar five.fivebn funding in Global Macro.
· · Equities LT net flows totaled dollar ninebn vs. our dollar eightbn estimate and dollar ninebn last quarter.
Fixed income LT flows were dollar sixbn for the quarter vs. our estimate of dollar fivebn and dollar fifteenbn last quarter.
On the hybrid side, LT flows of dollar sixbn came in below our expected dollar fivebn and dollar fourbn last quarter.
We note that results were inclusive of FX, which was a negative dollar one.sixbn
Capital deployment was above our expectations, with dollar four hundred fourmn of repurchases vs. our estimate of dollar three hundredmn, and a quarterly dividend of dollar .eighteen,
representing a twenty percent increase over last year's quarterly run rate.

Guide to the Barclays Fundamental Equity Research Rating System: Our coverage analysts use a relative rating system in which they rate stocks as Overweight, Equal Weight or Underweight relative to other companies covered by the analyst or a team of analysts that are deemed to be in the same industry .
In addition to the stock rating, we provide industry views which rate the outlook for the industry coverage universe as Positive, Neutral or Negative .
A rating system using terms such as buy, hold and sell is not the equivalent of our rating system.
Investors should carefully read the entire research report including the definitions of all ratings and not infer its contents from ratings alone.
Stock Rating Overweight The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelve month investment horizon.
Equal Weight The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelvemonth investment horizon.
Underweight The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelve month investment horizon.

Rating Suspended The rating and target price have been suspended temporarily due to market events that made coverage impracticable or to comply with applicable regulations and/or firm policies in certain circumstances including where the Investment Bank of Barclays Bank PLC is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or strategic transaction involving the company.
Neutral industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.

Guide to the Barclays Research Price Target: Each analyst has a single price target on the stocks that they cover.
The price target represents that analyst's expectation of where the stock will trade in the next twelve months.
Upside/downside scenarios, where provided, represent potential upside/potential downside to each analyst's price target over the same twelve month period.

Barclays Equity Research's Top Picks represent the single best alpha generating investment idea within each industry, taken from among the Overweight rated stocks within that industry.
Barclays Equity Research publishes global and regional Top Picks reports every quarter and analysts may also publish intra quarter changes to their Top Picks, as necessary.
While analysts may highlight other Overweight rated stocks in their published research in addition to their Top Pick, there can only be one Top Pick for each industry.
To view the current list of Top Picks, go to the Top Picks page on Barclays Live .

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: Risks include concentration in a small amount of key funds, soft equity and fixed income markets decreasing AUM or driving outflows, high leverage to retail customer segment, margin contraction from potential shift to lower fee products, as well as fee pressure and competition.
